channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chicago and Other Cities Say They Want Federal Agents Fighting Crime, Not Protesters
item.description: Rejecting the deployment of camouflaged federal agents, big-city mayors said the Trump administration should use its resources to help tackle problems like gun violence.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Charlie Savage and John Eligon
item.category: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives
item.media:credit: Pat Nabong/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago speaking last week. She and other mayors have spoken out against any plan to deploy anonymous federal officers to their cities.

item.title: The Virus Found a Crowded Houston Neighborhood, Sparing One Nearby
item.description: Two adjacent communities underscore the starkly divergent ways in which the coronavirus outbreak in Texas has attacked daily life.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents in the spacious homes of Bellaire, Texas, have largely avoided the coronavirus. But the virus has spread considerably in Gulfton, an adjacent community in Houston where people are packed into apartments.

item.title: Minneapolis Police Experience Surge of Departures in Aftermath of George Floyd Protests
item.description: The retention and recruitment problems that many police departments have experienced in recent years are especially pronounced after four Minneapolis officers were charged with Mr. Floyd’s death.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Andrea Ellen Reed for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s almost like a nuclear bomb hit the city, and the people who didn’t perish are standing around,” Officer Rich Walker Sr., a 16-year Minneapolis police veteran and union official, said of the mood within the department.

item.title: Andrew Gillum and the Long Shadow of the Florida Governor’s Race
item.description: The magnetic former Democratic nominee for Florida governor went from being a breakout political star to checking into rehab.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:description: Andrew Gillum lost the Florida governor’s race in 2018. He then threw himself into growing a voter-registration organization, fund-raising for the Democratic Party and commentating for CNN.

item.title: Its Top Curator Gone, SFMOMA Reviews Its Record on Race
item.description: The senior curator resigned amid anger among staff that boiled over when he used the term “reverse discrimination” — and now the museum is trying to address additional staff complaints.
item.dc:creator: Carol Pogash
item.category: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: SFMOMA is now having a wider discussion of race, and on Tuesday, the board chairman sent an email to staff in which he said the director “is committed to transforming SFMOMA into an anti-racist institution.”

item.title: Biden Could Quickly Reverse Trump’s Military Transgender Ban, Group Says
item.description: An advocacy group says the Pentagon would not need months to study how to allow transgender people to serve, because it had already done so to prepare the Obama policy that was reversed.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Progressive advocacy groups are hoping that a Biden presidency would undo a number of President Trump’s orders.

item.title: Sierra Club Says It Must Confront the Racism of John Muir
item.description: Muir, a monumental figure in American environmentalism and a Sierra Club founder, traded in “deeply harmful racist stereotypes,” the organization said.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins

item.title: Marciano Foundation Settles Lawsuit Over Layoffs
item.description: Each of the workers who was dismissed amid the labor dispute is expected to receive about 10 weeks of pay, said a lawyer who represented them.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.category: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.media:description: As part of the settlement with the Marciano Foundation, District Council 36 dropped a charge of unfair labor practices filed with the labor board, a union official said.

item.title: Study Links Gas Flares to Preterm Births, With Hispanic Women at High Risk
item.description: Expectant mothers who lived near flaring sites had higher odds of giving birth prematurely than those who did not, researchers found. The adverse outcomes fell entirely on Hispanic women.
item.dc:creator: Julia Rosen
item.media:description: A flare in Loving County, Texas. Energy companies flare natural gas when it is too abundant to capture and sell, or when low prices make doing so unprofitable.

item.title: Samantha Diaz, Florida Health Care Worker, Dies at 29
item.description: She left behind three children — two of whom have the novel coronavirus — in the care of her parents. “Our world came crashing down,” her mother said after Ms. Diaz died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye

item.title: E.P.A. Proposes Airplane Emission Standards That Airlines Already Meet
item.description: Staving off a lawsuit, the Environmental Protection Agency has proposed new regulations to hold airlines to the carbon dioxide emissions standards they created.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:description: Critics say the proposal does little more than codify a set of standards largely created by the aviation industry itself.

item.title: Portland Protest Tactics: Umbrellas, Pool Noodles and Fire
item.description: With no clear leaders or blueprints, demonstrators have scrounged for items from home and largely embraced a strategy of spontaneous consensus.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal forces and protesters clashed near the federal courthouse in Portland, Ore., early Wednesday.

item.title: Museum Directors Fear Permanent Closure, an Alliance Survey Shows
item.description: The American Alliance of Museums says that the Paycheck Protection Program “has served as a lifeline for many museums” during the pandemic, but they need more.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: How Much Will the Planet Warm if Carbon Dioxide Levels Double?
item.description: New research has sharply narrowed the range of outcomes.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Dead livestock in Ethiopia in 2016. “Narrowing the uncertainty” about temperature change is crucial for solid decision making, one of the report’s authors said.

item.title: The Fight for Fertility Equality
item.description: A movement has formed around the idea that one’s ability to build a family should not be determined by wealth, sexuality, gender or biology.
item.dc:creator: David Kaufman
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Warehouses Are Headed for the Central Valley, Too
item.description: Wednesday: The logistics industry has transformed the Inland Empire. Its next destination? The Central Valley.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Bethany Mollenkof for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warehouses have sprawled across the land in the Inland Empire.

item.title: Trump vs Biden Live Updates: President Reiterates Plan to Send Federal Agents to Democratic-Led Cities
item.description: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said that Ted Yoho’s remarks, after a confrontation on the steps of the Capitol, were ‘not an apology.’ A Trump campaign ad targeting Latino voters portrayed Democrats as extremists as it denounced the Goya boycott.
item.media:description: President Trump, whom polls show is trailing Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., has sought to make law enforcement a central focus of his re-election effort by painting Democratic cities and policies as lawless.

item.title: Back to Work
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: In Electric Car Market, It’s Tesla and a Jumbled Field of Also-Rans
item.description: Most traditional carmakers are struggling to produce and market electric vehicles even as Tesla sells hundreds of thousands of its luxury models.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Damon Casarez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Polestar, a new electric vehicle company backed by Volvo and its parent company, is opening sales centers in California and New York to compete with Tesla.

item.title: Portland Clashes Converge on Courthouse Named for an Antiwar Republican
item.description: The site where federal officers have fired tear gas and projectiles at protesters is named after a senator, Mark O. Hatfield, who described himself as “close” to being a pacifist.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clashed with protesters in front of the federal courthouse in Portland on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Northeast, Pummeled in the Spring, Now Stands Out in Virus Control
item.description: In just over two months, the Northeast has gone from the country’s worst coronavirus hot spot to its most controlled. “It’s acting like Europe,” one expert said.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Greta Rybus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diners observed social distancing and wore masks at Eventide restaurant in Portland, Maine, last month.

item.title: Trump Keeps Reminding People Polls Can Be Wrong
item.description: And if surveys of likely voters don’t look promising, turn to other measures. Like boat parades.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: President Trump has been trailing in national polls for over a month.

item.title: U.S. Orders China to Close Houston Consulate, Citing Efforts to Steal Trade Secrets
item.description: The Trump administration accused Chinese citizens of stealing scientific research and told the country’s diplomats in Texas to leave. Beijing warned it would retaliate.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Lara Jakes and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: U.S. officials said they had ordered the closure of the Chinese Consulate in Houston in response to repeated violations of American sovereignty.

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Puts Alaska Under Brief Tsunami Warning
item.description: The magnitude-7.8 earthquake was centered offshore, south of the Alaska Peninsula. There were no immediate reports of damage.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy

item.title: The Pandemic Isn’t Bringing Back Factory Jobs, at Least Not Yet
item.description: It’s a moment of reckoning for global supply chains. But that doesn’t mean companies are flocking back to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: “The global pandemic has proven once and for all that to be a strong nation, America must be a manufacturing nation,” President Trump said at a Ford factory in Ypsilanti, Mich., in May.

item.title: Army Soldier Sentenced to 3 Years in Accident That Killed West Point Cadet
item.description: Staff Sgt. Ladonies P. Strong, who was convicted of negligent homicide, was behind the wheel of a truck that overturned last year, killing one and injuring more than 20.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: A portrait of Christopher Morgan, who was killed in an accident in June 2019, on a chair beside graduating classmates last month.

item.title: Chicago Shooting: 14 People Shot Near Funeral Home
item.description: The shooting comes during a dispute between Mayor Lori Lightfoot and President Trump, who had said he would send federal agents to the city as it contends with violence.
item.dc:creator: Robert Chiarito and Will Wright
item.media:credit: Tyler Lariviere/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers investigated the scene where 14 people were shot in the Gresham neighborhood of Chicago on Tuesday.

item.title: Las Vegas Man Accused of ‘Thrill Killing’ of a Homeless Man
item.description: The police said Noah Green had later shot another man and had videos of both attacks on his cellphone.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: “We believe that we have taken a very dangerous person off of the streets,” Lt. Raymond Spencer of the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police said at a news conference on Monday.

item.title: Homeland Security Leaders on Defensive Amid Calls to Withdraw From Portland
item.description: The department’s acting secretary met with reporters and blamed local Oregon officials amid criticism that he has gone too far to suppress protests in Portland.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Chad Wolf, the acting homeland security secretary, defended agents who have been accused of placing protesters in unmarked vans without telling them where they are going.

item.title: Powerful Ohio Republican Is Arrested in $60 Million Corruption Scheme
item.description: The House speaker was connected with a conspiracy to enact a $1.3 billion bailout of an energy company, the F.B.I. said.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:description: Larry Householder, the Republican speaker of Ohio’s House of Representatives.

item.title: Trump, in a Shift, Endorses Masks and Says Virus Will Get Worse
item.description: Rather than just “embers” of the disease, as he has repeatedly characterized recent outbreaks afflicting much of the country, President Trump conceded that there were now “big fires.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump on Tuesday held his first televised coronavirus briefing since he had called them off in late April.

item.title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Embraces Republican Ted Yoho's Insult
item.description: Representative Ted Yoho reportedly approached Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on the steps of the Capitol, calling her “disgusting” for her policies and uttering a pair of expletives.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez in Queens last month. She arrived on Capitol Hill in 2019 with an outsize profile and has frequently been a target of derision by white Republican men.

item.title: As Trump Pushes Into Portland, His Campaign Ads Turn Darker
item.description: The Trump campaign is spending millions on ads that promote a dark and exaggerated portrayal of Democratic-led cities, a tactic that reinforces his “law and order’’ campaign message.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Nick Corasaniti and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clashed with protesters in Portland, Ore., on Tuesday. President Trump has strained to tie images of unrest in American cities to his Democratic opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr.

item.title: Trump Campaign Ads Depict His Own Lawless Dystopia
item.description: For the past three weeks, the Trump campaign has been spending tens of millions of dollars on ads depicting a protest movement out of control, both to stoke fear among his base and rationalize his deployment decisions.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Judge Declines to Release Girl, 15, Held for Skipping Online Schoolwork
item.description: The Michigan teenager has been in a juvenile detention facility since May after she violated probation terms by skipping her school’s remote-learning coursework.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested outside a courthouse in Pontiac, Mich., last week in support of a student who was being held in a juvenile detention facility for not keeping up with her online schoolwork.

item.title: Republicans Heap Criticism on Liz Cheney, Calling Her Disloyal to Trump
item.description: In an extraordinary intraparty airing of grievances, House Republicans lashed out at their third-ranking leader, who has sometimes broken with the president but until now escaped the ire of his closest allies.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:description: Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming is one of the most conservative Republicans in the House.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The U.S. military may be spreading the virus, and the C.D.C. says the real number of cases is far higher than the official count.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Police Find Body in Building Burned Down During George Floyd Protests
item.description: The body was found at the site of a Minneapolis pawnshop that was set on fire just days after the death of Mr. Floyd.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.category: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives
item.media:description: A Minneapolis pawnshop burning in late May during protests that followed the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Rise in Virus Cases Near Bases in U.S. and Abroad Poses Test for Military
item.description: American military officials are trying to contain the spread of the coronavirus in its ranks while tackling logistical problems like relieving troops overseas.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Paratroopers wear masks at Fort Bragg, N.C. More than 80 soldiers there tested positive for the coronavirus last month.
